text: there was a time when I first started to
understand the true magnitude and scope
of the archive that it would make a huge
impact on the world but I think even
thinking about in Hong Kong what the
likely outcome would be or even the
best-case-scenario outcome would be
we really didn't dream that it would be
this intense and sustained of a global
debate and that's what's made it so
gratifying and yet you almost passed on
the entire story right it wasn't so much
that I passed on it it was that when
Edward Snowden was contacting me he
could only speak to me in an unencrypted
environment and for reasons that in
retrospect are quite rational he was
unwilling to really share with me
anything about what he had or who he was
and so without his doing that these were
these very vague missives asking me to
drop what I was doing and install
sophisticated programs and without his
sharing with me something about who he
was I never had the motivation to do it
so you're right though I did almost lose
out on the story and when he first met
him you were surprised by Edward
Snowden's youth you were expecting
someone at the end of that career taking
a huge risk absolutely I remember that
point I knew he had access to huge
numbers of very sensitive documents I
also had spent a long time talking to
him online and his insights were
uniformly sophisticated all of which
made me think he was senior but the
principal reason was that he I knew he
was ready to risk his life to go to
prison he wanted to be identified not to
hide which made me think that he must
have been around for a long time becomes
so disillusioned to take that risk now
critics are what of what you have done
say that mass surveillance by the US
government is necessary to protect lives
what do you say to that the point of
9/11 was that the US government failed
to detect the plot not because they
hadn't collected enough but that they
had collected so much that they didn't
even know the meaning of what they had
and the response to this was to say
we're now going to collect not just more
but everything and the problem is that
when you're collecting billions with a B
of calls and emails every day which is
what they're collecting it's almost
impossible to detect people who are
planning an attack on the Boston
Marathon or to exploit a plane above
Detroit on Christmas Day it becomes
overwhelming and and the targets of
their surveillance Petrobras and the
German Chancellor and economic summits
really give the lie to the claim that
this is about national security
you know that that mass surveillance
hasn't saved lives don't we only hear
about the failures we know because the
people who have access to all of the
secret information people like
Democratic senators Ron Wyden and mark
Udall who are on the Senate Intelligence
Committee the president's own advisory
panel who studied this in a classified
setting the federal court that ruled it
unconstitutional all have said that the
NSA is incapable of identifying any
actual terrorists they were able to
apprehend as a result in these programs
there's just zero evidence for it and no
specific cases where it happened but
would you accept that some degree of
surveillance is necessary sure I don't
think anybody in the world that I've
ever heard and I've been writing about
these issues for a long time takes the
position that there's no legitimate
surveillance the question is are you
surveilling the people or there's
evidence to believe they're actually
engaged in wrongdoing are you
surveilling entire populations in a
suspicionless context and it's the
latter which is what makes it so
disturbing well President Obama has
announced changes to the NSA program in
the wake of your revelations what do you
make of the changes the history of the
US government when they got caught doing
things that the public is outraged by
and secret is to offer the pretense or
the gesture of reform but not really to
reform in any meaningful way what they
were caught doing and and I think that
some of the reforms in Washington not
from Obama but from the house are steps
in the right direction but I think real
reform is going to come from a
combination of other countries banding
together the tech companies demanding
changes because they perceive it as a
threat to their business but most of all
individuals starting to protect their
own communications through the use of
encryption that the NSA actually can't
invade you talk to Edward Snowden all
the time to see have any regrets he does
not have a single regret he's probably
the most self-actualized and and
tranquil person I know in my life is he
worried about being in Russia though a
government where recently they asked
bloggers to register I mean you know
people seek asylum in all kinds of
countries all the time including the
United States that have all kinds of
human rights abuses in their record the
idea of asylum is to get protection from
persecution so he'd been choose Russia
he was forced to stay there as he was
trying to leave by the US government but
I think he's been essentially free to
participate in the debate he catalyzed
and that's the most important thing
now you've said that you've saved the
best firework for last the best
revelation what is it it isn't so much
that I saved it it's that it's the story
that hasn't yet been told because the
reporting on this story is so
complicated and takes so much time and
you know I can't obviously talk about
the story before it's ready I'd love to
break the news here on this set but the
question that is missing from the
surveillance debate so far are things
like exactly who have they targeted for
domestic spying what kinds of people do
they consider sufficient threats I think
so I think it's going to help inform the
debate in a very serious way Glenn
Greenwald thank you for being with us
thank you very much for having me
